title: Disgraced GP’s ‘breathtaking’ act
text:
A disgraced doctor jailed for trafficking a “breathtaking” amount of prescription drugs to a bikie gang using his Brisbane-based clinic has suffered another court blow while trying to appeal his sentence.

Dr Robert John Ullman is serving a 6½ year jail term after pleading guilty to one count of trafficking in dangerous drugs between January 1, 2018 and September 22, 2020, and nine counts of supplying a dangerous drug.

Over the two years, Ullman unlawfully trafficked schedule 2 prescription drugs – mostly benzodiazepines – through his Chermside clinic and through an unqualified gym owner who handed out drugs and received cash payments from the customers.

Dr John Robert Ullman trafficked dangerous drugs through his Brisbane clinic, often to members of the Comanchero bikie gang. Picture: NewsWire/ Dan Peled

They were predominantly sold to members of the Comanchero outlaw motorcycle gang, at times booked in for normal appointments.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

At his sentencing in April, Brisbane Supreme Court was told Ullman sold the drugs to 31 different people on 76 occasions.

The court was told the turnover was more than $1.5m.

Six months after his sentence was imposed, Ullman launched an appeal to challenge his 2028 parole eligibility date – claiming the sentence was “manifestly excessive”.

He argued the sentencing judge’s reasons did not reveal how the mitigating circumstances had been taken into account in arriving at the parole eligibility date.

Ullman submitted there was a departure from the norm of imposing a parole eligibility date of one-third of that sentence with no explanation.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

In its published judgment, the Court of Appeal dismissed Ullman’s appeal, stating his legal team had not demonstrated why the sentence was excessive.

Ullman argued his sentence was ‘manifestly excessive’ due to a 2028 parole eligibility date. Picture: NewsWire/ Dan Peled

Justices Bradley, Doyle and Wilson said it was wrong to view the “starting point” of Ullman’s sentence – being the 6½ year period – as the head sentence when his mitigating factors were taken into account, then to ask whether a standard non-parole period should be applied.

“This requires an approach which artificially fragments the sentencing process,” Justice Doyle wrote in the judgment.

“The sentencing judge retains the discretion to determine the appropriate early parole date, and that discretion is not so rigidly fettered in the way that the applicant’s case assumes.”

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

At the end of the police operation targeting Ullman, his house and clinic were searched.

Police located luxury products, cash in the amount of $338,760 and a large amount of benzodiazepine and testosterone.

“It was accepted that his professional earnings, apart from his trafficking and supply earnings, were significant and would have either enabled or contributed to the collection of the luxury products,” the judgment states.

The Court of Appeal noted some of the circumstances of Ullman’s offending and how serious they were.

They included Ullman being a medical practitioner “in whom the public reposed faith and confidence, abused that to traffic drugs on a sustained scale”, that he did it for commercial gain and the trafficking was “carried out in an attempted clandestine form, being paid in some instances in cash, using encrypted communication devices”.

Ullman was caught with luxury products and more than $338,000 worth of cash when his home and clinic were searched by police. Picture: NewsWire/ Dan Peled

Ullman only stopped when detected by police and he encouraged customers to turn to the black market for drugs he could not supply, the judgment continues.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“Everything that could sensibly be urged in mitigation was said on the applicant’s behalf and taken into account by the sentencing judge,” the judgment states.

“The result is not in my view manifestly excessive.

“The outcome … would not be disturbed if this court was called upon to re-exercise the sentencing power.”

Ullman’s mitigating factors included the loss of his professional standing and career, the loss of his family relationship and his rehabilitation efforts in the four years since.

It was also submitted that he may have been in over his head being involved with supplying customers “who were members of an outlaw motorcycle gang”.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The trafficking charge carried a maximum penalty of 25 years’ jail.

In 2020, the Health Ombudsman suspended Ullman’s registration as a medical practitioner when the charges were first laid.

He has no approval to practise in any employment or practice location.

title: Minister 'concerned' at setting migration targets
text:
The number of migrants coming to Australia needs to come down, the immigration minister says, but a set multi-year target would not be helpful.

Tony Burke said the migration intake was continuing to fall and was 40 per cent below its peak in the aftermath of the COVID pandemic.

While the Department of Home Affairs has announced plans to commit to a four-year immigration target, Mr Burke said that would not be the right approach.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"What I am concerned about is if you overcommit where you will be at in future years, you miss some of the changed needs of the nation that we have," Mr Burke told ABC's Insiders program on Sunday.

Australia's migration level needs to come down, but a set target is unhelpful, Tony Burke says. (Lukas Coch/AAP PHOTOS)

"I never want to have a situation where we feel committed because we announced this is where we'd be three years earlier, and we lose some of the flexibility we need to take advantage of exactly what Australia needs."

In September, the federal government announced 185,000 permanent visas would be made available in 2025/26, leaving the rates unchanged from the previous financial year.

Mr Burke said the overall migration rate would be tailored to what the country needs.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"The net overseas migration figure we're expecting will continue to soften ... and that's just getting us to appropriate levels post-pandemic," he said.

Opposition home affairs spokesman Jonathon Duniam said the government should carry out a methodical process for determining what future migration levels looked like.

"It's time for (the government) to be transparent about how they're factoring all of these things in, like housing, health, education, public services, as to how they get the numbers," he told Sky News.

The minister appealed for debate around immigration levels to be done in a respectful way. (Darren England/AAP PHOTOS)

"Australians broadly agree, and indeed the minister himself has said, that (the migration level) is too high."

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The minister stressed the need to keep the debate surrounding migration respectful.

"People used to talk about being able to engage in dog whistle politics, and you give a message, and only certain people would really hear what you were saying. It's not a dog whistle any more. It's a set of bag pipes coming over the hill," he said.

"We are a multicultural nation, and when people sledge multicultural Australia, there are a whole lot of Australian citizens who hear it, feel it deeply."

title: The tiny $120 features popping up on beaches around Australia
text:
Next time you visit your local beach, take a moment to look around for a small white capsule. They're usually attached to fences or trees near beach entrances, and though they may look unassuming, they could save your life.

The $120 capsules are packed with medical equipment to help in the event of a shark bite. While they were only launched a year ago, strong community support has seen the initiative expanded to more than 85 beaches around the country – with dozens more on the way.

The shark bite kits were the brainchild of Danny Schouten, who almost lost his friend Kai McKenzie to a shark attack at North Shore Beach in Port Macquarie last year. Kai lost his leg in the incident, but was there to support Danny on the day he launched the kits and has since returned to surfing.

Danny (left) and Kai in October last year after installing the first shark bite kit on the same beach where Kai was attacked. Source: Instagram.com/communitysbk/

Paramedic raises thousands for more shark bite kits

Paramedic, ex-lifeguard and keen surfer Liam Brett has never met Danny in person, but felt compelled to help the cause to give beachgoers immediate access to equipment that could make the difference between life and death.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"Ever since I became a paramedic, I have kept two tourniquets in my car for myself and my friends. And just a thought crossed my mind that no one else would do that. No one else has that there," he told Yahoo News.

Liam set out with a goal to raise about $4,000 for 35 new kits to install himself at beaches between Tweed Heads and Ballina. In just a few weeks, his goal was surpassed with an extra $2,300 raised.

All additional funds will be put towards more shark bite kits, which will be installed at even more beaches further north.

This map pinpoints the exact locations of all current shark bite kits. So far, most of them have been installed along the east coast. Source: Instagram.com/communitysbk/

"It's been unreal, it's gone even beyond what I was aiming for, which is great," Liam said, praising the Tweed and Byron communities for their support.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"It's now being expanded to the islands, south and north Stradbroke, hopefully K'gari and Moreton as well. Places that need it."

The exact locations of all the current kits can be found on this map.

Why are the kits needed?

With his medical background, Liam knows every second matters when dealing with trauma – especially if an artery has been severed.

He referenced an incident in June at Cabarita Beach when a 16-year-old boy was bitten by a shark on his right arm and right leg. There happened to be off-duty paramedics on the beach at the time, who made a makeshift tourniquet to stop the bleeding, but he feared the outcome could've been different if there were no health professionals around.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"You can bleed out in less than a minute from your femoral artery. A smaller artery, obviously the longer it takes to bleed out and it depends what pressure is applied, but it can be well under a minute if you sever a major artery," he said.

"I think it's important that people have the right equipment because even if there's an ambulance around the corner, they're not going to be on the beach with the tourniquet with the patient in less than a minute."

The tourniquets inside the kit could be the difference between life and death. Source: Instagram.com/communitysbk/

What's in the kit?

Liam's raised funds get sent to Danny, who then supplies the kits completely ready for installation.

"He [Danny] is doing an amazing job. He has made it really easy for someone like me to help out and jump on board. This is absolutely Danny's thing, I'm just helping get them to this particular area, and hopefully more people will do that for their local area," he said.

Each kit contains:

• 2 tourniquets

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

• 2 large dressings

• 2 compression bandages

• Thermal blanket

• Amputated parts bags

• Whistle

• Gloves

• Step-by-step shark bite management card

To fund a shark bite kit, visit Liam's GoFundMe page here.
